name: Sisig
description: Sisig is a sizzling Kapampangan snack made from chopped pork face and liver, seasoned with tangy calamansi and a kick of chili.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork face and liver, finely chopped
instructions: Boil the pork until tender, then grill or fry until slightly crispy.
Finely chop the meat and combine with red onion and chilies.
Season with calamansi juice, soy sauce, salt, and pepper.
Mix lightly with mayonnaise if desired and serve hot on a sizzling plate.

name: Tocino
description: Tocino is a sweet and savory cured pork dish from Kapampangan cuisine—perfect for breakfast or as a main course.
instructions: Marinate the pork belly in brown sugar, soy sauce, garlic, and annatto powder for at least 4 hours.
Fry the marinated pork in a pan until well caramelized and cooked through.
Slice and serve with garlic fried rice and a sunny-side-up egg.

name: Bringhe
description: Bringhe is a Kapampangan-style paella featuring glutinous rice cooked in coconut milk with shrimp and a warm hint of turmeric.
instructions: Sauté garlic in a bit of oil until aromatic.
Add shrimp and quickly sauté until just pink.
Stir in glutinous rice, coconut milk, turmeric, and diced bell pepper.
Season with salt and pepper and simmer gently until the rice is tender and creamy.
Serve garnished with extra bell pepper if desired.

name: Pindang Damulag
description: Pindang Damulag is a savory Kapampangan dish featuring tender carabao meat simmered in vinegar with aromatic spices.
ingredients: 1/2 kg carabao meat, cut into chunks
instructions: Boil the carabao meat until tender.
Sauté garlic and onion in a pan until soft.
Add the boiled meat, vinegar, and bay leaf; simmer for 10 minutes.
Adjust seasonings and serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Kamaru
description: Kamaru is a traditional Kapampangan breakfast dish that blends the savory flavor of crab with a hint of sweetness from raisins.
instructions: Combine crab meat with green peas, raisins, beaten eggs, and garlic.
Mix in vinegar and season with salt and pepper.
Lightly steam or pan-fry the mixture until set.
Serve warm as a unique breakfast dish.

name: Betute Tugak
description: Betute Tugak is a Kapampangan snack featuring delicate pork belly layered with vegetables and bound with an egg-liver mixture.
instructions: Marinate the pork slices in vinegar with salt and pepper.
Mix liver spread with beaten eggs and water to form a binder.
Layer the pork with carrots and onions, then pour the egg mixture over it.
Steam until the pork is tender, then slice and serve hot.

name: Tidtad
description: Tidtad is a savory Kapampangan side dish that combines shrimp, cheese, and a touch of sweetness from raisins.
instructions: Sauté onions in oil until translucent.
Add shrimp and cook until just done.
Stir in liver spread, raisins, cheese, and breadcrumbs.
Season with salt and pepper, and simmer for a few minutes.
Serve hot as a flavorful side dish.

name: Morcon
description: Morcon is a festive Kapampangan meat roll filled with a well-seasoned mixture of pork, vegetables, and raisins.
instructions: Mix ground pork with minced carrot, onion, garlic, raisins, green peas, eggs, salt, and pepper.
Shape the mixture into a log and wrap tightly in foil.
Steam the log until cooked through, then slice into rounds.
Pan-fry the slices briefly until the exterior is browned and crisp, and serve hot.

name: Embutido
description: Embutido is a classic Kapampangan meatloaf made with pork belly, vegetables, raisins, and cheese for a savory treat.
instructions: Thoroughly mix all the ingredients.
Shape the mixture into a log and wrap tightly in foil.
Steam for 45 minutes until firm.
Slice and lightly pan-fry for a crispy exterior, then serve.

name: Lechon Kawali
description: Lechon Kawali is a celebrated Kapampangan dish featuring crispy, deep-fried pork belly served with a tangy dipping sauce.
instructions: Boil the pork belly in salted water with garlic until tender.
Allow the meat to cool, then pat dry thoroughly.
Deep-fry the pork belly until the skin becomes crispy and golden.
Cut into bite-sized pieces and serve with a vinegar and garlic dipping sauce.

name: Kare-Kare
description: Kare-Kare is a rich and savory stew from Kapampangan cuisine, featuring tender oxtail in a peanut sauce with fresh vegetables.
instructions: Boil the oxtail or tripe until tender.
Mix peanut butter and annatto water into the broth, stirring well.
Add eggplant and bok choy; simmer for a few additional minutes.
Season with salt and add ground roasted rice if a thicker sauce is desired.
Serve hot with a side of shrimp paste.

name: Bopis
description: Bopis is a spicy and tangy Kapampangan dish featuring finely chopped pork offal sautéed with vinegar and spices.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork lungs and heart, finely chopped
instructions: Sauté garlic and onions until soft.
Add chopped offal and cook until well browned.
Stir in vinegar, chilies, salt, and black pepper; let simmer for 15 minutes.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Dinuguan
description: Dinuguan is a traditional Filipino pork blood stew with a rich, tangy flavor—an integral dish in Kapampangan cuisine.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork meat and offal, diced
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion until fragrant.
Add pork and offal, cooking until lightly browned.
Slowly pour in pork blood and vinegar while stirring to prevent curdling.
Simmer until the sauce thickens and flavors meld.
Season with salt and pepper, then serve with steamed rice.

name: Paksiw na Lechon
description: Paksiw na Lechon is a savory dish where roasted lechon is simmered in a tangy vinegar sauce with garlic and spices.
ingredients: 1 whole roasted lechon, cut into pieces
instructions: Combine vinegar, garlic, onion, and bay leaf in a pot; bring to a simmer.
Add lechon pieces and simmer for 15 minutes so they absorb the tangy flavors.
Adjust seasoning with salt and pepper, then serve with steamed rice.

name: Kalderetang Kambing
description: Kalderetang Kambing is a hearty goat stew from Kapampangan cuisine, simmered with vegetables in a rich tomato sauce.
ingredients: 1 kg goat meat, cut into chunks
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion in oil until soft.
Brown goat meat on all sides.
Pour in tomato sauce and add sufficient water to cover the meat.
Add potatoes, carrots, and bell pepper; simmer until the meat is tender.
Season with salt and pepper, then serve hot with rice.

name: Chicharon Bulaklak
description: Chicharon Bulaklak is a crispy Kapampangan snack made from deep-fried pork mesentery, enjoyed for its crunchy texture and savory flavor.
instructions: Clean and prepare the pork mesentery thoroughly.
Season with salt and pepper.
Deep-fry in hot oil until crispy and golden brown.
Drain on paper towels and serve with a vinegar-based dipping sauce.

name: Menudo
description: Menudo is a classic Filipino stew in Kapampangan style featuring tender pork with vegetables simmered in a savory tomato sauce.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork, cut into small cubes
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion until translucent.
Brown the pork cubes thoroughly.
Add tomato sauce along with potatoes, carrots, and bell pepper.
Simmer until vegetables are tender and meat is cooked through.
Season with salt and pepper, and serve hot with rice.

name: Afritada
description: Afritada is a comforting chicken stew from Kapampangan cuisine, simmered in tomato sauce with hearty vegetables.
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion until soft in oil.
Add chicken pieces and brown lightly.
Stir in tomato sauce, potatoes, and carrots; simmer until the chicken is tender.
Add bell peppers in the last 5 minutes of cooking.
Season with salt and pepper and serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Adobong Puti
description: Adobong Puti is a tangy version of Filipino adobo that highlights the sourness of vinegar and the aroma of garlic.
ingredients: Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
instructions: Sauté garlic in oil until golden.
Add chicken pieces and brown on all sides.
Pour in vinegar and add bay leaves.
Cover and simmer until the chicken is tender and flavors meld.
Adjust seasoning and serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Bulanglang
description: Bulanglang is a unique Kapampangan dish combining tender chicken with eggs, raisins, and a hint of cheese for a rich flavor.
instructions: Season chicken slices with salt and pepper and lightly sauté until just cooked.
Pour in beaten eggs and stir in garlic, carrots, and raisins.
Cook over low heat until the egg mixture is set and slightly creamy.
Stir in grated cheese just before turning off the heat, then serve immediately.

name: Gatang Kuhol
description: Gatang Kuhol is a robust Kapampangan stew featuring carabao meat simmered with vegetables and eggs in a savory broth.
instructions: Sauté garlic and onions in oil until soft.
Add diced carabao meat and brown on all sides.
Pour in water and bring to a boil.
Stir in beaten eggs, raisins, green peas, salt, and pepper.
Simmer until the meat is tender and the sauce thickens slightly, then serve hot with rice.

name: Paksiw na Isda
description: Paksiw na Isda is a tangy and savory fish dish where tilapia is gently simmered in a mixture of vinegar and aromatics.
instructions: Place tilapia in a pot with sliced tomato and onion.
Pour in water and vinegar, then add garlic, salt, and pepper.
Bring to a simmer and cook until the fish is tender and infused with the sour flavor.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Arroz Valenciana
description: Arroz Valenciana is a creamy Kapampangan rice dish enriched with crab meat and coconut milk, offering a unique blend of flavors.
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion in oil until soft.
Add crab meat and stir briefly.
Mix in glutinous rice and coconut milk; bring to a gentle simmer.
Cook until the rice is tender and creamy.
Stir in breadcrumbs, adjust seasoning, and serve hot.

name: Kilayin
description: Kilayin is a tangy and savory Kapampangan breakfast dish made with diced chicken cooked in vinegar and garlic.
instructions: Heat oil in a pan and sauté garlic until fragrant.
Add diced chicken and cook until lightly browned.
Pour in water and vinegar; add red chili if desired.
Simmer until the chicken is tender and flavors meld.
Season with salt and pepper, then serve hot with rice.

name: Pork Asado
description: Pork Asado is a sweet and savory Kapampangan dish featuring tender pork sirloin marinated in a caramelized brown sugar mixture.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork sirloin, cut into cubes
instructions: Marinate pork cubes in brown sugar, soy sauce, and garlic for 3–4 hours.
Sear the pork in a hot pan until caramelized.
Add water and simmer until the meat is tender.
Adjust seasoning and serve hot with garlic fried rice.

name: Nilagang Baka
description: Nilagang Baka is a comforting beef stew in Kapampangan cuisine, simmered with vegetables for a hearty meal.
instructions: Boil the beef shank with onions and garlic until tender.
Add potatoes and cabbage; simmer until vegetables are cooked.
Season with salt and pepper, then serve hot with rice.

name: Sinigang na Baboy
description: Sinigang na Baboy is a tangy pork sour soup—a beloved Kapampangan dish known for its refreshing, sour broth.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork belly, cut into pieces
Tamarind soup base or fresh tamarind
instructions: Boil the pork belly with tomato and onion until tender.
Add tamarind base and radishes and simmer for a few minutes.
Stir in kangkong and adjust salt before serving with rice.

name: Ginisang Monggo
description: Ginisang Monggo is a hearty mung bean stew enjoyed for breakfast in Kapampangan households, rich in aromatics and flavor.
ingredients: Water or chicken broth as needed
instructions: Drain and boil the mung beans until soft.
In a separate pan, sauté garlic, onion, and tomato until tender.
Combine the boiled mung beans with the sautéed aromatics and simmer for 10 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper and serve hot with rice.

name: Tokwa't Baboy
description: Tokwa't Baboy is a classic Filipino dish combining tender pork with crispy tofu in a tangy garlic-vinegar dressing.
ingredients: 1/2 kg pork belly, boiled and sliced
200g firm tofu, cubed and fried until golden
instructions: Combine boiled pork belly and fried tofu in a serving bowl.
Mix in minced garlic and vinegar, and season with salt and pepper.
Garnish with chopped onions and serve as an appetizer or side dish.

name: Pritong Lumpia
description: Pritong Lumpia is a crispy Filipino spring roll filled with a savory pork and vegetable mixture, a popular Kapampangan snack.
instructions: Mix ground pork with carrots, cabbage, garlic, and onion; season with salt and pepper.
Place a spoonful of the filling on each lumpia wrapper and roll tightly.
Deep-fry the lumpia until golden and crispy.
Drain on paper towels and serve with a sweet-sour dipping sauce.

name: Pancit Luglug
description: Pancit Luglug is a flavorful Kapampangan noodle dish served with a rich pork broth and a generous cheese topping.
instructions: Boil the rice noodles until tender, then drain.
Warm the pork broth and toss with the noodles.
Top with grated cheese, sautéed onions, and sliced red chili.
Season with salt and serve immediately.

name: Pancit Palabok
description: Pancit Palabok is a festive Kapampangan noodle dish topped with shrimp broth, chicharon, boiled eggs, and crispy garlic.
instructions: Boil the rice noodles until al dente, then arrange on a serving plate.
Warm the shrimp broth and mix in the flaked tilapia.
Pour the broth mixture over the noodles.
Top with crushed chicharon, boiled eggs, and crispy garlic.
Season with salt and pepper and serve immediately.

name: Ginataang Langka
description: Ginataang Langka is a hearty Kapampangan dish featuring pork belly and unripe jackfruit simmered in creamy coconut milk.
ingredients: 1 small unripe jackfruit (langka), cut into strips
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion until fragrant.
Add pork belly and cook until slightly browned.
Stir in jackfruit and pour in coconut milk.
Simmer until the pork is tender and the flavors meld.
Season with salt and pepper and serve hot with rice.

name: Ginataang Puso ng Saging
description: Ginataang Puso ng Saging is a unique Kapampangan dish where tilapia is gently simmered with banana hearts in a creamy coconut milk sauce.
ingredients: 1 cup banana hearts (puso ng saging), sliced
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion until softened.
Add tilapia and cook briefly.
Mix in banana hearts and coconut milk.
Simmer until the sauce thickens slightly.
Season with salt and pepper and serve hot.

name: Laing
description: Laing is a classic Kapampangan dish made from dried taro leaves cooked in coconut milk with a hint of shrimp paste, balancing spicy and savory flavors.
instructions: Rinse the taro leaves thoroughly.
Sauté garlic, onion, and red chilies until fragrant.
Add the taro leaves and quickly stir-fry.
Pour in coconut milk and simmer until the leaves soften.
Stir in coconut cream and bagoong; adjust salt and simmer for an additional 10 minutes.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Ukoy
description: Ukoy is a crispy Filipino fritter made with shrimp and vegetables, a well-loved snack in Kapampangan cuisine.
instructions: Combine shrimp, bean sprouts, grated squash, beaten egg, and rice flour in a bowl.
Season the mixture with salt and pepper.
Drop spoonfuls into hot oil and fry until the patties are crispy and golden.
Drain on paper towels and serve with a vinegar dipping sauce.

name: Tortang Talong
description: Tortang Talong is a popular Filipino breakfast dish where grilled eggplant is dipped in egg and fried until crispy.
instructions: Grill the eggplants until the skin is charred and the flesh softens.
Peel off the skin carefully and flatten the eggplants.
Dip each eggplant in beaten eggs, seasoning with salt and pepper.
Pan-fry until golden brown on both sides, then serve hot.

name: Inihaw na Bangus
description: Inihaw na Bangus is a classic grilled milkfish from Kapampangan cuisine, marinated in garlic and calamansi for a fresh, tangy flavor.
instructions: Marinate the bangus with garlic, calamansi juice, salt, and pepper for at least 30 minutes.
Brush the fish with oil and grill over medium heat until cooked through with slight charring.
Serve hot with steamed rice and a side of fresh salad.

name: Rellenong Bangus
description: Rellenong Bangus is a stuffed milkfish dish in Kapampangan cuisine, featuring a savory mixture of fish, vegetables, and egg.
ingredients: 1/2 cup mixed vegetables (carrot and bell pepper), finely chopped
instructions: Mix the flaked milkfish with chopped vegetables, onion, and beaten egg; season with salt and pepper.
Option 1: Stuff the mixture into the cleaned bangus skin and roll; pan-fry until golden. Option 2: Form the mixture into patties and fry until crispy.
Serve hot with a dipping sauce and steamed rice.

name: Tinolang Manok
description: Tinolang Manok is a comforting chicken soup in Kapampangan style, enriched with green papaya and leafy greens.
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion in a pot until translucent.
Add chicken pieces and lightly brown them.
Pour in water or broth and simmer until the chicken is tender.
Add green papaya and cook until just softened.
Mix in chili leaves, season with salt and pepper, and simmer briefly before serving.

name: Chicken Inasal
description: Chicken Inasal is a signature Kapampangan grilled chicken marinated in a tangy and garlicky mixture with vibrant annatto oil.
ingredients: 1 whole chicken, cut into serving pieces
instructions: Marinate the chicken in calamansi juice, soy sauce, garlic, annatto oil, salt, and pepper for at least 3 hours.
Grill the chicken over medium heat, basting with extra marinade until charred and cooked through.
Serve hot with garlic rice and a side of pickled vegetables.

name: Pastel
description: Pastel is a Kapampangan savory roll filled with a delicate mixture of shrimp and vegetables, steamed to perfection.
instructions: Combine shrimp, diced vegetables, beaten egg, and soy sauce; season with salt and pepper.
Place a portion of the mixture on a lumpia wrapper and roll tightly.
Steam the rolls for 20 minutes until set, then slice and optionally pan-fry the edges for extra crispiness.
Serve warm.

name: Pininyahang Manok
description: Pininyahang Manok features tender chicken simmered in a sweet and savory coconut milk sauce with pineapple and bell pepper.
instructions: Sauté garlic until fragrant, then add chicken and lightly brown.
Pour in coconut milk and add pineapple and bell pepper.
Simmer until the chicken is tender and the sauce thickens slightly.
Season with salt and pepper and serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Ginataang Manok
description: Ginataang Manok is a comforting chicken dish in Kapampangan style, simmered in creamy coconut milk with a hint of sweetness from vegetables.
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion in oil until softened.
Add chicken pieces and brown lightly.
Pour in coconut milk and add sliced carrot.
Simmer until the chicken is fully cooked and the sauce is creamy.
Season with salt and pepper and serve hot with rice.

name: Leche Flan
description: Leche Flan is a rich and creamy Filipino custard dessert with a silky texture and a sweet, golden caramel topping.
instructions: Melt sugar in a pan until golden to create a caramel; pour it into your flan mold.
Whisk together egg yolks, condensed milk, and evaporated milk until smooth.
Pour the custard mixture over the caramel in the mold.
Steam in a water bath for 30-40 minutes, or bake in a preheated oven at 350°F until set.
Chill thoroughly before serving.

name: Brazo de Mercedes
description: Brazo de Mercedes is a delicate rolled dessert with a light meringue exterior and a rich, sweet egg yolk custard filling.
instructions: Beat egg whites with sugar until stiff peaks form to create a light meringue.
Spread the meringue thinly on a baking sheet and bake at low heat until firm.
In a saucepan, gently cook egg yolks with condensed milk and vanilla until a thick custard forms.
Spread the custard over the baked meringue and roll it tightly.
Refrigerate before slicing and serving.

name: San Nicolas Cookies
description: San Nicolas Cookies are melt-in-your-mouth Filipino treats with a tender center and crisp edges—a traditional dessert from Kapampangan homes.
instructions: Cream together butter and sugar until light and fluffy.
Mix in the egg and vanilla extract.
Sift together flour, baking powder, and salt; incorporate into the butter mixture.
Shape dough into small cookies and bake at 350°F for 12-15 minutes until lightly golden.
Cool completely and serve.

name: Turon
description: Turon is a beloved Filipino snack of caramelized saba bananas and jackfruit wrapped in a crispy spring roll wrapper.
instructions: Coat each banana slice in brown sugar and place a few jackfruit strips along the edge.
Roll tightly in a lumpia wrapper, sealing the edge with a little water.
Deep-fry until crispy and golden brown.
Drain on paper towels and serve warm.

name: Bibingka
description: Bibingka is a traditional Filipino rice cake with a soft, slightly chewy texture and a subtle coconut flavor, often enjoyed during celebrations.
instructions: Combine rice flour, sugar, and baking powder in a bowl.
Stir in coconut milk and melted butter until a smooth batter forms.
Line a baking pan with banana leaves and pour in the batter.
Bake at 375°F for 25-30 minutes until set and lightly golden.
Serve warm, optionally dusted with extra sugar.

name: Puto Bumbong
description: Puto Bumbong is a festive Filipino purple rice cake steamed in bamboo tubes, traditionally enjoyed during the Christmas season.
instructions: Soak glutinous rice in water overnight.
Steam the soaked rice in bamboo tubes or a mold until soft.
Serve with grated coconut and a sprinkling of sugar on top.

name: Kutsinta
description: Kutsinta is a chewy Filipino steamed rice cake with a gelatinous texture and subtle sweetness, best enjoyed with grated coconut.
instructions: Mix rice flour with lye water until smooth.
Dissolve brown sugar in water and combine with the flour mixture.
Pour the batter into molds and steam for 25-30 minutes until set.
Serve topped with freshly grated coconut.

name: Sapin-Sapin
description: Sapin-Sapin is a vibrant Filipino layered rice cake with a sweet, chewy texture and an eye-catching presentation.
instructions: Mix glutinous rice flour, coconut milk, and sugar to form a smooth batter.
Divide the batter into portions and add different food colorings to each.
Layer the colored batters in a greased pan.
Steam for 45-60 minutes until firm.
Cool, slice, and garnish with toasted coconut flakes.

name: Buko Pandan
description: Buko Pandan is a refreshing Filipino dessert featuring young coconut, pandan-flavored jelly, and a creamy, sweet dressing.
ingredients: 1 pack pandan jelly (prepared according to package instructions)
instructions: Mix the shredded coconut with diced fruits.
Fold in the pandan jelly cubes.
Add condensed milk and heavy cream; stir until well combined.
Chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours before serving.

name: Halo-Halo
description: Halo-Halo is the ultimate Filipino dessert—a colorful mix of sweet fruits, beans, milk, and ice that refreshes on hot days.
ingredients: Assorted sweet beans and fruits (e.g., red mung beans, jackfruit, banana)
instructions: Layer sweet beans and fruits at the bottom of a tall glass.
Fill the glass with crushed ice and pour evaporated milk over it.
Top with slices of leche flan and a scoop of ube ice cream.
Add shaved ice if desired and serve immediately.

name: Ube Halaya
description: Ube Halaya is a creamy and vibrantly colored Filipino dessert made from purple yam, enriched with coconut and condensed milk.
instructions: Mash the boiled ube until smooth.
Melt butter in a pan and add the mashed ube.
Stir in coconut milk, condensed milk, and sugar.
Cook on low heat while stirring continuously until the mixture thickens.
Pour into a mold, allow to cool, and serve as a rich dessert.

name: Maja Blanca
description: Maja Blanca is a smooth, creamy Filipino pudding made with coconut milk and corn, garnished with a sprinkle of cheese.
instructions: Combine coconut milk, corn, cornstarch, and sugar in a saucepan.
Cook over medium heat, stirring until the mixture thickens and pulls away from the sides.
Pour into a greased dish and allow to cool.
Refrigerate for a few hours before topping with grated cheese and serving.

name: Palitaw
description: Palitaw is a traditional Filipino rice cake made from glutinous rice, coated with sweetened grated coconut.
instructions: Soak the glutinous rice in water overnight.
Shape the rice into small, flat cakes and steam until cooked.
Roll the cooked cakes in a mixture of grated coconut and sugar, and serve warm.

name: Cassava Cake
description: Cassava Cake is a dense, sweet Filipino dessert made from cassava and coconut milk, often enjoyed during festive occasions.
instructions: Combine grated cassava, coconut milk, condensed milk, sugar, and melted butter in a bowl.
Pour the mixture into a greased baking pan.
Bake at 350°F for 45 minutes or until the cake is set and golden on top.
Sprinkle grated cheese on top and serve warm.

name: Pichi-Pichi
description: Pichi-Pichi is a soft, chewy Filipino dessert made from grated cassava, often vibrantly colored and coated in fresh coconut.
instructions: Cook grated cassava, sugar, and water over medium heat until thickened.
Add a few drops of red food coloring for a vibrant hue, if desired.
Spoon the mixture into small molds and let it set.
Roll the set cakes in grated coconut before serving.

name: Puto
description: Puto is a soft, steamed Filipino rice cake that is light and slightly sweet—perfect as a snack or side dish.
instructions: Mix rice flour, baking powder, sugar, egg, and water to form a smooth batter.
Pour the batter into small molds and steam for 15-20 minutes until a toothpick comes out clean.
Top with grated cheese if desired, and serve warm.

name: Suman
description: Suman is a traditional Filipino sticky rice cake wrapped in banana leaves, enjoyed as a snack or breakfast treat.
instructions: Mix glutinous rice with coconut milk and sugar.
Wrap portions of the mixture in banana leaves.
Steam the wrapped rice cakes for 30-40 minutes until fully cooked.
Serve warm, optionally drizzled with coconut caramel (latik).

name: Nilupak
description: Nilupak is a velvety Filipino dessert made from mashed cassava or bananas, simmered in coconut milk and condensed milk.
ingredients: 2 cups mashed cassava (or mashed saba bananas)
instructions: Combine the mashed cassava (or saba) with coconut milk, condensed milk, and sugar.
Cook over low heat while stirring continuously until the mixture thickens.
Transfer to a greased pan, smooth the surface, and let cool.
Cut into squares and serve as a comforting dessert.

name: Ginataang Bilo-Bilo
description: Ginataang Bilo-Bilo is a comforting Filipino dessert featuring chewy rice balls, sweet potato, and tapioca pearls in a creamy coconut milk broth.
instructions: In a pot, combine coconut milk, sugar, diced sweet potato, and salt; bring to a simmer.
Add the glutinous rice balls and cooked sago, and simmer until everything is soft and the sauce thickens slightly.
Serve warm or chilled.

name: Banana Cue
description: Banana Cue is a popular Filipino street snack of caramelized saba bananas deep-fried to perfection.
instructions: Heat oil in a deep pan.
Roll each banana in brown sugar until evenly coated.
Deep-fry until the sugar caramelizes and the bananas turn golden.
Drain on paper towels and serve warm, ideally on a skewer.

name: Camote Cue
description: Camote Cue is a Filipino snack of sweet potatoes coated in caramelized brown sugar and deep-fried until crispy.
ingredients: 4 medium sweet potatoes (camote), peeled and cut into chunks
instructions: Heat oil in a deep pan.
Coat each sweet potato chunk in brown sugar.
Deep-fry until the sugar melts, forming a crisp, caramelized coating.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot.

description: Kalamay is a popular dish in Kapampangan cuisine.
